member.summary: Performs evaluation and replacement of independent sub-trees

A function that decides whether a given expression node can be part of the local function.

member.summary: Evaluates and replaces sub-trees when first candidate is reached (top-down)

member.name: T:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.Utils.PartialEvaluator.Nominator
member.summary: Performs bottom-up analysis to determine which nodes can possibly be part of an evaluated sub-tree.

The aggregate name.

member.name: M:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.LightSpeedQueryOperators.WithViewName``1(System.Linq.IQueryable{``0},System.String)
member.summary: Associates a view with a query.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements of .
member.param: An with which to associate the view.
The view name.
member.returns: An which will perform the same query, but over the specified view instead of the standard table.
member.remarks: This extension will execute the same behavior as UnitOfWork.Query[T](viewName). If you are repeatedly using a view then the other approach may be preferrable and can be specified as part of your typed UnitOfWork using a partial class

member.name: T:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.Plan.GroupResultsPlan
member.summary: A query plan for performing roll-ups of grouping queries into the expected set of client side collections associated with an entity key which is not performed by the LightSpeed core
member.remarks: REVIEW NEEDED: This plan is used by GroupBy. Potentially we have some cross-over here with the ProjectGrouping action and we should look to review if these can be merged, ideally into ProjectGrouping with this plan being removed

member.name: M:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.Plan.GroupResultsPlan.GenerateKeyMapFromReader(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Mindscape.LightSpeed.Querying.Group},System.Data.IDataReader,Mindscape.LightSpeed.LightSpeedContext)
member.summary: Creates a simple mapping of index between grouping keys and the position of the record in the reader
member.remarks: Currently should be sufficient for what we need, however this may likely fall down when the field names are not simple and we need to determine the table alias, and or column alias to be able to map properly

member.name: T:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.Plan.MultipleQueryPlan
member.summary: A query plan for handling execution and merging of two or more inner queries
member.remarks:
DESIGN DECISION SERVER/CLIENT: This plan primarily supports the multi-set SQO's such as Concat, Union, Intersect and SequenceEqual some of which we probably dont want to support because they would mask poorly running queries
REVIEW: Some of this behavior can actually be performed client side, so we should investigate if this is the case given the improvements made with Selectable

member.name: T:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.ServerFunctionDescriptor
member.summary: Represents a server-side function such as a built-in SQL function or a UDF.

member.name: M:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.ServerFunctionDescriptor.Register(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.String)
member.summary: Registers a mapping from a CLR method to a server-side function.
member.param: The CLR method to be mapped.
The server-side function name.

member.name: M:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.ServerFunctionDescriptor.Register(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Registers a mapping from a CLR method to a server-side function.
member.param: The CLR method to be mapped.
The server-side function name.
The position in the server-side function's argument list at which the client-side implicit ('this') argument appears.
member.remarks: To illustrate the use of implicitArgumentIndex, consider the following client-side query: from m in uow.Members select m.UserName.IndexOf('a'). On SQL Server this translates to CHARINDEX('a', UserName): i.e. the object to which IndexOf was applied appears at index 1 in CHARINDEX's argument list. So the implicitArgumentIndex should be 1.

member.name: M:Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.Sqo.JoinBase.ProcessJoinConditionExpression(Mindscape.LightSpeed.Linq.Plan.LinqQueryPlanExpression,Mindscape.LightSpeed.Querying.IAttributePathExpression,Mindscape.LightSpeed.Querying.Selectable)
member.remarks: If there is a traversal to be managed then we need to use the ExtractJoinsForJoinCriteria walk to walk the traversal path and join as required. Simple scenarios only require us to return a join condition specifying the path returned in the PathExpression
